text: "Philosophy," says Hierocles, "is the purification and perfection of human
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: life. It is the purification, indeed, from material irrationality, and the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: mortal body; but the perfection, in consequence of being the resumption of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: our proper felicity, and a reascent to the divine likeness. To effect these
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: two is the province of Virtue and Truth; the former exterminating the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: immoderation of the passions; and the latter introducing the divine form to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: those who are naturally adapted to its reception."
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Of philosophy thus defined, which may be compared to a luminous pyramid,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: terminating in Deity, and having for its basis the rational soul of man
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and its spontaneous unperverted conceptions,--of this philosophy, August,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: magnificent, and divine, Plato may be justly called the primary leader
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and hierophant, through whom, like the mystic light in the inmost
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: recesses of some sacred temple, it first shone forth with occult and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: venerable splendour.[1] It may indeed be truly said of the whole of this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: philosophy, that it is the greatest good which man can participate: for
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: if it purifies us from the defilements of the passions and assimilates us
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to Divinity, it confers on us the proper felicity of our nature. Hence it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is easy to collect its pre-eminence to all other philosophies; to show
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that where they oppose it, they are erroneous; that so far as they
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: contain any thing scientific they are allied to it; and that at best they
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: are but rivulets derived from this vast ocean of truth.

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

text: To evince that the philosophy of Plato possesses this preeminence; that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: its dignity and sublimity are unrivaled; that it is the parent of all
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that ennobles man; and, that it is founded on principles, which neither
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: time can obliterate, nor sophistry subvert, is the principal design of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: this Introduction.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: To effect this design, I shall in the first place present the reader with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the outlines of the principal dogmas of Plato's philosophy. The undertaking
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is indeed no less novel than arduous, since the author of it has to tread
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in paths which have been untrodden for upwards of a thousand years, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to bring to light truths which for that extended period have been
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: concealed in Greek. Let not the reader, therefore, be surprised at the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: solitariness of the paths through which I shall attempt to conduct him,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: or at the novelty of the objects which will present themselves in the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: journey: for perhaps he may fortunately recollect that he has traveled
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the same road before, that the scenes were once familiar to him, and that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the country through which he is passing is his native land. At, least, if
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: his sight should be dim, and his memory oblivious, (for the objects which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: he will meet with can only be seen by the most piercing eyes,) and his
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: absence from them has been lamentably long, let him implore the power
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of wisdom,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: From mortal mists to purify his eyes,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: That God and man he may distinctly see.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Let us also, imploring the assistance of the same illuminating power, begin
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the solitary journey.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Of all the dogmas of Plato, that concerning the first principle of things
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: as far transcends in sublimity the doctrine of other philosophers of a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: different sect, on this subject, as this supreme cause of all transcends
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: other causes. For, according to Plato, the highest God, whom in the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Republic he calls the good, and in the Parmenides the one, is not only
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: above soul and intellect, but is even superior to being itself. Hence,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: since every thing which can in any respect be known, or of which any
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: thing can be asserted, must be connected with the universality of things,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: but the first cause is above all things, it is very properly said by
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Plato to be perfectly ineffable. The first hypothesis therefore of his,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Parmenides, in which all things are denied of this immense principle,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: concludes as follows: "The one therefore is in no respect. So it seems.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Hence it is not in such a manner as to be one, for thus it would be
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: being, and participate of essence; but as it appears, the one neither is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: one, nor is, if it be proper to believe in reasoning of this kind. It
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: appears so. But can any thing either belong to, or be affirmed of that,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which is not? How can it? Neither therefore does any name belong to it,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: nor discourse, nor any science, nor sense, nor opinion. It does not
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: appear that there can. Hence it can neither be named, nor spoken of, nor
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: conceived by opinion, nor be known, nor perceived by any being. So it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: seems." And here it must be observed that this conclusion respecting the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: highest principle of things, that he is perfectly ineffable and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: inconceivable, is the result of a most scientific series of negations, in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which not only all sensible and intellectual beings are denied of him,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: but even natures the most transcendently allied to him, his first and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: most divine progeny. For that which so eminently distinguishes the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: philosophy of Plato from others is this, that every part of it is stamped
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with the character of science. The vulgar indeed proclaim the Deity to be
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: ineffable; but as they have no scientific knowledge that he is so, this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is nothing more than a confused and indistinct perception of the most
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sublime of all truths, like that of a thing seen between sleeping and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: waking, like Phaeacia to Ulysses when sailing to his native land,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: That lay before him indistinct and vast,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Like a broad shield amid the watr'y waste.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: In short, an unscientific perception of the ineffable nature of the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Divinity resembles that of a man, who on surveying the heavens, should
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: assert of the altitude of its highest part, that it surpasses that of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the loftiest tree, and is therefore immeasurable. But to see this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: scientifically, is like a survey of this highest part of the heavens by
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the astronomer; for he by knowing the height of the media between us and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it, knows also scientifically that it transcends in altitude not only the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: loftiest tree; but the summits of air and aether, the moon, and even the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sun itself.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Let us therefore investigate what is the ascent to the ineffably, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: after what manner it is accomplished, according to Plato, from the last
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of things, following the profound and most inquisitive Damascius as our
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: leader in this arduous investigation. Let our discourse also be common
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to other principles, and to things proceeding from them to that which is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: last, and let us, beginning from that which is perfectly effable and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: known to sense, ascend too the ineffable, and establish in silence, as in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: a port, the parturitions of truth concerning it. Let us then assume the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: following axiom, in which as in a secure vehicle we may safely pass from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: hence thither. I say, therefore, that the unindigent is naturally prior
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to the indigent. For that which is in want of another is naturally
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: adapted from necessity to be subservient to that of which it is indigent.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: But if they are mutually in want of each other, each being indigent of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the other in a different respect, neither of them will be the principle.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: For the unindigent is most adapted to that which is truly the principle.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: And if it is in want of any thing, according to this it will not be the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principle. It is however necessary that the principles should be this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: very thing, the principle alone. The unindigent therefore pertains to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: this, nor must it by any means be acknowledged that there is any thing
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: prior to it. This however, would be acknowledged if it had any connection
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with the indigent.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Let us then consider body, (that is, a triply extended substance,) endued
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with quality; for this is the first thing effable by us, and is, sensible.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Is this then the principle of things? But it is two things, body, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: quality which is in body as a subject. Which of these therefore is by
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: nature prior? For both are indigent of their proper parts; and that also
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which is in a subject is indigent of the subject. Shall we say then that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: body itself is the principle of the first essence? But this is impossible.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: For, in the first place, the principle will not receive any thing from that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which is posterior to itself. But body, we say is the recipient of quality.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Hence quality, and a subsistence in conjunction with it, are not derived
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: from body, since quality is present with body as something different. And,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in the second place, body is every way, divisible; its several parts are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: indigent of each other, and the whole is indigent of all the parts. As it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is indigent, therefore, and receives its completion from things which are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: indigent, it will not be entirely unindigent.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Further still, if it is not one but united, it will require, as Plato
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: says, the connecting one. It is likewise something common and formless,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: being as it were a certain matter. It requires, therefore, ornament and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the possession of form, that it may not be merely body, but a body with a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: certain particular quality; as for instance, a fiery, or earthly, body,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and, in short, body adorned and invested with a particular quality. Hence
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the things which accede to it, finish and adorn it. Is then that which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: accedes the principle? But this is impossible. For it does not abide in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself, nor does it subsist alone, but is in a subject of which also it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is indigent. If, however, some one should assert that body is not a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: subject, but one of the elements in each, as for instance, animal in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: horses and man, thus also each will be indigent of the other, viz. this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: subject, and that which is in the subject; or rather the common element,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: animal, and the peculiarities, as the rational and irrational, will be
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: indigent. For elements are always, indigent of each other, and that which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is composed from elements is indigent of the elements. In short, this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sensible nature, and which is so manifest to us, is neither body, for
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: this does not of itself move the senses, nor quality; for this does not
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: possess an interval commensurate with sense. Hence, that which is the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: object of sight, is neither body nor color; but colored body, or color
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: corporalized, is that which is motive of the sight. And universally, that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which its sensible, which is body with a particular quality, is motive of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sense. From hence it is evident that the thing which excites the sense is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: something incorporeal. For if it was body, it would not yet be the object
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of sense. Body therefore requires that which is incorporeal, and that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which is incorporeal, body. For an incorporeal nature, is not of itself
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sensible. It is, however, different from body, because these two possess
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: prerogatives different from each other, and neither of these subsists
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: prior to the other; but being elements of one sensible thing, they are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: present with each other; the one imparting interval to that which is void
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of interval, but the other introducing to that which is formless,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sensible variety invested with form. In the third place, neither are both
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: these together the principles; since they are not unindigent. For they
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: stand in need of their proper elements, and of that which conducts them
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to the generation of one form. For body cannot effect this, since it is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of itself impotent; nor quality, since it is not able to subsist separate
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: from the body in which it is, or together with which it has its being.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The composite therefore either produces itself, which is impossible, for
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it does not converge to itself, but the whole of it is multifariously
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: dispersed, or it is not produced by itself, and there is some other
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principle prior to it.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Let it then be supposed to be that which is called nature, being a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principle of motion and rest, in that which is moved and at rest,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: essentially and not according to accident. For this is something more
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: simple, and is fabricative of composite forms. If, however, it is in the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: things fabricated, and does not subsist separate from nor prior to them,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: but stands in need of them for its being, it will not be unindigent;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: though its possesses something transcendent with respect to them, viz.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the power of fashioning and fabricating them. For it has its being
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: together with them, and has in them an inseparable subsistence; so
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that, when they are it is, and is not when they are not, and this in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: consequence of perfectly verging to them, and not being able to sustain
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that which is appropriate. For the power of increasing, nourishing, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: generating similars, and the one prior to these three, viz. nature, is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: not wholly incorporeal, but is nearly a certain quality of body, from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which it alone differs, in that it imparts to the composite to be
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: inwardly moved and at rest. For the quality of that which is sensible
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: imparts that which is apparent in matter, and that which falls on sense.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: But body imparts interval every way extended; and nature, an inwardly
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: proceeding natural energy, whether according to place only, or according
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to nourishing, increasing, and generating things similar. Nature,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: however, is inseparable from a subject, and is indigent, so that it will
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: not be in short the principle, since it is indigent of that which is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: subordinate. For it will not be wonderful, if being a certain principle,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it is indigent of the principle above it; but it would be wonderful if it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: were indigent of things posterior to itself, and of which it is supposed
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to be the principle.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: By the like arguments we may show that the principle cannot be irrational
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: soul, whether sensitive, or orectic. For if it appears that it has
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: something separate, together with impulsive and Gnostic enemies, yet at
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the same time it is bound in body, and has something inseparable from it;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: since it is notable to convert itself to itself, but its enemy is mingled
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with its subject. For it is evident that its essence is something of this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: kind; since if it were liberated and in itself free, it would also evince
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: a certain independent enemy, and would not always be converted to body;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: but sometimes it would be converted to itself; or though it were always
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: converted to body, yet it would judge and explore itself. The energies,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: therefore, of the multitude of mankind, (though they are conversant with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: externals,) yet, at the same time they exhibit that which is separate
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: about them. For they consult how they should engage in them, and observe
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that deliberation is necessary, in order to effect or be passive to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: apparent good, or to decline something of the contrary. But the impulses
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of other animals are uniform and spontaneous, are moved together with the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sensible organs, and require the senses alone that they may obtain from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sensibles the pleasurable, and avoid the painful. If, therefore, the body
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: communicates in pleasure and pain, and is affected in a certain respect
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: by them, it is evident that the psychical energies, (i.e. energies
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: belonging to the soul) are exerted, mingled with bodies, and are not
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: purely psychical, but are also corporeal; for perception is of the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: animated body, or of the soul corporalized, though in such perception the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: psychical idiom predominates over the corporeal; just as in bodies, the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: corporeal idiom has dominion according to interval and subsistence. As
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the irrational soul, therefore, has its being in something different from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself, so far it is indigent of the subordinate: but a thing of this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: kind will not be the principle.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Prior them to this essence, we see a certain form separate from a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: subject, and converted to itself, such as is the rational nature. Our
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: soul, therefore, presides over its proper energies and corrects itself.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: This, however, would not be the case, unless it was converted to itself;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and it would not be converted, to itself unless it had a separate
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: essence. It is not therefore indigent of the subordinate. Shall we then
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: say that it is the most perfect principle? But, it does not at once exert
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: all its energies, but is always indigent of the greater part. The
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principle, however, wishes to have nothing indigent: but the rational
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: nature is an essence in want of its own energies. Some one, however, may
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: say that it is an eternal essence, and has never-failing essential
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: energies, always concurring with its essence, according to the self-moved
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and ever vital, and that it is therefore unindigent; but the principle is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: perfectly unindigent. Soul therefore, and which exerts mutable energies,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: will not be the most proper principle. Hence it is necessary that there
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: should be something prior to this, which is in every respect immutable,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: according to nature, life, and knowledge, and according to all powers and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: enemies, such as we assert an eternal and immutable essence to be, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: such as is much honoured intellect, to which Aristotle having ascended,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: thought he had discovered the first principle. For what can be wanting to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that which perfectly comprehends in itself its own plenitudes (oleromata),
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and of which neither addition nor ablation changes any thing belonging to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it? Or is not this also, one and many, whole and parts, containing in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself, things first, middle, and last? The subordinate plenitudes also
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: stand in need of the more excellent, and the more excellent of the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: subordinate, and the whole of the parts. For the things related are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: indigent of each other, and what are first of what are last, through the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: same cause; for it is not of itself that which is first. Besides, the one
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: here is indigent of the many, because it has its subsistence in the many.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Or it may be said, that this one is collective of the many, and this not
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: by itself, but in conjunction with them. Hence there is much of the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: indigent in this principle. For since intellect generates in itself its
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: proper plenitudes from which the whole at once receives its completion,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it will be itself indigent of itself, not only that which is generated of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that which generates, but also that which generates, of that which is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: generated, in order to the whole completion of that which wholly generates
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself. Further still, intellect understands and is understood, is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: intellective of and intelligible to itself, and both these. Hence the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: intellectual is indigent of the intelligible, as of its proper object of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: desire; and the intelligible is in want of the intellectual, because it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: wishes to be the intelligible of it. Both also are indigent of either,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: since the possession is always accompanied with indigence, in the same
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: manner as the world is always present with matter. Hence a certain
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: indigence is naturally coessentiallized with intellect, so that it cannot
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: be the most proper principle. Shall we, therefore, in the next place,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: direct our attention to the most simple of beings, which Plato calls the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: one being, [Greek: en on]? For as there is no separation there throughout
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the Whole, nor any multitude, or order, or duplicity, or conversion to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself, what indigence will there appear to me, in the perfectly united?
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: And especially what indigence will there be of that which is subordinate?
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Hence the great Parmenides ascended to this most safe principle, as that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which is most unindigent. Is it not, however, here necessary to attend to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the conception of Plato, that the united is not the one itself, but that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which is passive[2] to it? And this being the case, it is evident that it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: ranks after the one; for it is supposed to be the united and not the one
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself. If also being is composed from the elements bound and infinity,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: as appears from the Philebus of Plato, where he calls it that which is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: mixt, it will be indigent of its elements. Besides, if the conception of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: being is different from that of being united, and that which is a whole
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is both united and being, these will be indigent of each other, and the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: whole which is called one being is indigent of the two. And though the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: one in this is better than being, yet this is indigent of being, in order
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to the subsistence of one being. But if being here supervenes the one, as
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it were, form in that which is mixt and united, just as the idiom of man
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in that which is collectively rational-mortal-animal, thus also the one
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: will be indigent of being. If, however, to speak more properly, the one
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is two-fold; this being the cause of the mixture, and subsisting prior to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: being, but that conferring rectitude, on being,--if this be the case,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: neither will the indigent perfectly desert this nature. After all these,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it may be said that the one will be perfectly unindigent. For neither is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it indigent of that which is posterior to itself for its subsistence,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: since the truly one is by itself separated from all things; nor is it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: indigent of that which is inferior or more excellent in itself; for there
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is nothing in it besides itself; nor is it in want of itself. But it is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: one, because neither has it any duplicity with respect to itself. For not
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: even the relation of itself to itself must be asserted of the truly one;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: since it is perfectly simple. This, therefore, is the most unindigent of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: all things. Hence this is the principle and the cause of all; and this is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: at once the first of all things. If these qualities, however, are present
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with it, it will not be the one. Or may we not say that all things
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: subsist in the one according to the one? And that both these subsist in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it, and such other things as we predicate of it, as, for instance, the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: most simple, the most excellent, the most powerful, the preserver of all
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: things, and the good itself? If these things, however, are thus true of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the one, it will thus also be indigent of things posterior to itself,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: according to those very things which we add to it. For the principle is,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and is said to be the principle of things proceeding from it, and the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: cause is the cause of things caused, and the first is the first of things
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: arranged, posterior to it.[3]

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: subsistence of these.

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: things, the most powerful according to power with relation to the subjects
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of it; and the good, the desirable, and the preserving, are so called with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: reference to things benefitted, preserved, and desiring. And if it should
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: be said to be all things according to the preassumption of all things in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself, it will indeed be said to be so according to the one alone, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: will at the same time be the one cause of all things prior to all, and will
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: be thus, and no other according to the one. So far, therefore, as it is the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: one alone, it will be unindigent; but so far as unindigent, it will be the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: first principle, and stable root of all principles. So far, however, as it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is the principle and the first cause of all things, and is pre-established
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: as the object of desire to all things, so far it appears to be in a certain
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: respect indigent of the things to which it is related. It has therefore, if
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it be lawful so to speak, an ultimate vestige of indigence, just as on the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and debile impression of the one. And language indeed appears to be here
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: subverted. For so far as it is the one, it is also unindigent, since the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principle has appeared to subsist according to the most unindigent and the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: one. At the same time, however, so far as it is the one, it is also the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principle; and so far as it is the one it is unindigent, but so far as the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principle, indigent. Hence so far as it is unindigent, it is also indigent,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: though not according to the same; but with respect to being that which it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is, it is undigent; but as producing and comprehending other things in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself, it is indigent. This, however, is the peculiarity of the one; so
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that it is both unindigent and indigent according to the one. Not indeed
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: than it is each of these, in such a manner as we divide it in speaking of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it, but it is one alone; and according to this is both other things, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that which is indigent. For how is it possible, it should not be indigent
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: also so far as it is the one? Just as it is all other things which proceed
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: from it. For the indigent also is, something belonging to all things.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: converted to, it surveys itself. For when extended to things external, it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Again, therefore, that we may return to the proposed object of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: investigation, how can a self-motive nature of this kind, which is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: mingled with the alter-motive, be the first principle of things? For
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it neither subsists from itself, nor does it in reality perfect itself;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: but it requires a certain other nature, both for its subsistence and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: perfection: and prior to it is that which is truly self-moved. Is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: therefore that which is properly self-moved the principle, and is it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: indigent of no form more excellent than itself? Or is not that which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: moves always naturally prior to that which is moved; and in short does
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: not every form which is pure from its contrary subsist by itself prior
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to that which is mingled with it? And is not the pure the cause of the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: commingled? For that which is coessentialized with another has also an
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: energy mingled with that other. So that a self-moved nature will indeed,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: make itself; but thus subsisting it will be at the same time moving and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: moved, but will not be made a moving nature only. For neither is it this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: alone. Every form however is always alone according to its first
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: subsistence; so that there will be that which moves only without being
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: moved. And indeed it would be absurd that there should be that which is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: moved only such as body, but that prior both to that which is self-moved
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and that which is moved only, there should not be that which moves only.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: nature, and that which is self-moved, so far as it moves itself, is more
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: excellent than so far as it is moved. It is necessary therefore that the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: essence which moves unmoved, should be first, as that which is moved, not
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: being motive, is the third, in the middle of which is the self-moved,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which we say requires that which moves in order to its becoming motive.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: In short, if it is moved, it will not abide, so far as it is moved; and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: if it moves, it is necessary it should remain moving so far as it moves.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Whence then does it derive the power of abiding? For from itself it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: derives the power either of being moved only, or of at the same time
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: abiding and being moved wholly according to the same. Whence then does
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it simply obtain the power of abiding? Certainly from that which simply
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: abides. But, this is an immovable cause. We must therefore admit that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the immovable is prior to the self moved. Let us consider then if the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: immovable is the most proper principle? But how is this possible? For the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: immovable contains as numerous a multitude immovably; as the self-moved
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: prior to a self-moveable separation. The unmoved therefore is at the same
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: time one and many, and is at the same time united and separated, and a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: nature of this kind is denominated intellect. But it is evident that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: separated. For separation is always indigent of union; but not, on the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: possessing in one contraction multitude, subsisting prior to the many.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Having therefore arrived thus far, let us here rest for a while, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: consider with ourselves, whether being is the investigated principle of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: all things. For what will there be which does not participate of being?
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: May we not say, that this, if it is the united, will be secondary to the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: one, and that by participating of the one it becomes the united? But in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: short; if we conceive the one to be something different from being, if
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: being is prior to the one, it will not participate of the one. It will
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: therefore be many only, and these will be infinitely infinite. But if the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: or divided from each other, there will be two principles, and the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: above-mentioned absurdity will happen. Or they will mutually participate
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of each other, and there will be two elements. Or they are parts of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that be which leads them to union with each other? For if the one unites
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: being to itself (for this may be said), the one also will energize prior
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to being, that it may call forth and convert being to itself. The one,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: therefore, will subsist from itself self-perfect prior to being. Further
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: still, the more simple is always prior to the more composite. If
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: or one from the two, and this will be a composite. Hence the simple and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: one; and if not one, it must either be many, or nothing. But with respect
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

author: Taylor, Thomas

text: No less admirably, therefore, than Platonically does Simplicius, in his
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Commentary of Epictetus, observe on this subject as follows: "The
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: things desire, and to which all things are extended, is the principle and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the end of all things. The good also produces from itself all things,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: first, middle, and last. But it produces such as are first and proximate
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to itself, similar to itself; one goodness, many goodnesses, one
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: simplicity and unity which transcends all others, many, unities, and one
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principle many principles. For the one, the principle, the good, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: deity, are the same: for deity is the first and the cause of all things.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: But it is necessary that the first should also be most simple; since
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: whatever is a composite and has multitude is posterior to the one. And
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: multitude and things, which are not good desire the good as being above
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: them: and in short, that which is not itself the principle is from the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principle.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: But it is also necessary that the principle of all things should possess
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the highest, and all, power. For the amplitude of power consists in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: producing all things from itself, and in giving subsistence to similars,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: prior to things which are dissimilar. Hence the one principle produces
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: many principles, many simplicities, and many goodnesses, proximately from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself. For since all things differ from each other, and are multiplied
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with their proper differences, each of these multitudes is suspended from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: its one proper principle. Thus, for instance, all beautiful things,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: whatever and wherever they may be, whether in souls or in bodies, are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: suspended from one fountain of beauty. Thus too, whatever possesses
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: symmetry, and whatever is true, and all principles, are in a certain
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: respect, connate with the first principle, so far as they are principles
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and fountains and goodnesses, with an appropriate subjection and analogy.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: For what the one principle is to all beings, that each of the other
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principles is to the multitude comprehended under the idiom of its
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principle. For it is impossible, since each multitude is characterized
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: by a certain difference, that it should not be extended to its proper
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principle, which illuminates one and the same form to all the individuals
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of that multitude. For the one is the leader of every multitude; and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: every peculiarity or idiom in the many is derived to the many from the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: one. All partial principles therefore are established in that principle
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which ranks as a whole, and are comprehended in it, not with interval and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: multitude, but as parts in the whole, as multitude in the one, and number
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in the monad. For this first principle is all things prior to all: and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: goodness, many goodnesses are established. This too, is not a certain
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and which is the principle of principles.

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: (See vol. iii, p. 133). For as we have observed from Proclus, in the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: always comprehends, according to cause that which it produces, it is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: begotten, and produced by itself. If the one therefore is not self-sub-
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Besides, as Damascius well observes, if that which is subordinate by
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: intellect. And if it be true of intellect, it will also be true of life: if
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of life, of being likewise; and if of being, of the unities above being.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: For the self-perfect, the self-sufficient, and that which is established in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself, will much more subsist in superior than in subordinate natures. If
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: therefore, these are in the latter, they will also be in the former. I mean
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the subsistence of a thing by itself, and essentialized in itself; and such
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: are essence and life, intellect, soul, and body. For body, though it does
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: not subsist from, yet subsists by itself; and through this belongs to the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: genus of substance, and is contra-distinguished from accident, which cannot
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: exist independent of a subject.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas
