title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: conceived as something even more excellent than this. From this divine
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: self-perfect and self-producing multitude, a series of self-perfect
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: natures, viz. of beings, lives, intellects, and souls proceeds, according
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to Plato, in the last link of which luminous series he also classes the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: human soul; proximately suspended from the daemoniacal order: for this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: order, as he clearly asserts in the Banquet, "stands in the middle rank
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: between the divine and human, fills up the vacant space, and links
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: penetrated the depths of Plato's philosophy, it will doubtless appear
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself, and yet at the same time proceed from a superior cause. The
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: solution of this difficulty is as follows:--Essential production, or that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: energy through which any nature produces something else by its very
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: being, is the most perfect mode of production, because vestiges of it are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: seen in the last of things; thus fire imparts heat, by its very essence,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and snow coldness. And in short, this is a producing of that kind, in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which the effect is that secondarily which the cause is primarily. As
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: this mode of production therefore, from its being the most perfect of all
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: others, originates from the highest natures, it will consequently first
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: belong to those self-subsistent powers, who immediately proceed from the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: ineffable, and will from them be derived to all the following orders of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: beings. But this energy, as being characterized by the essential, will
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: necessarily be different in different producing causes. Hence, from that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which subsists, at the summit of self subsistent natures, a series of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: self subsisting beings will indeed proceed, but then this series will be
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: secondarily that which its cause is primarily, and the energy by which it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: produces itself will be secondary to that by which it is produced by its
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: cause. Thus, for instance, the rational soul both produces itself (in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: consequence of being a self-motive nature), and is produced by intellect;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: but it is produced by intellect immutably, and by itself transitively;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: for all its energies subsist in time, and are accompanied with motion. So
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: far therefore as soul contains intellect by participation, so far it is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: produced by intellect, but so far as it is self-motive it is produced by
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself. In short, with respect to every thing self-subsistent, the summit
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of its nature is produced by a superior cause, but the evolution of that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: summit is its own spontaneous energy; and, through this it becomes
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: self-subsistent, and self-perfect.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: this with great propriety; for all divine natures, and such things as
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: splendour. Hence, since the souls imparts life and motion to other
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: things, on which account Aristotle calls an animal antokincton, self-
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: moved, it will much more, and by a much greater priority, impart life and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: motion to itself.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: From this magnificent, sublime, and most scientific doctrine of Plato,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: respecting the arcane principle of things and his immediate progeny, it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: not through any defect, but on the contrary through transcendency of power.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: divine media are necessary to the fabrication of the world. For if the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: universe was immediately produced from the ineffable, it would, agreeably
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to what we have above observed, be ineffable also in a secondary degree.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: But as this is by no means the case, it principally derives its immediate
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

text: Again, since Plato employs fables, let us in the first place consider
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: whence the ancients were induced to devise fables, and in the second place,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: what the difference is between the fables of philosophers and those of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: poets. In answer to the first question then, it is necessary to know that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the ancients employed fables looking to two things, viz. nature, and our
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: soul. They employed them by looking to nature, and the fabrication of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: things, as follows. Things unapparent are believed from things apparent,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and incorporeal natures from bodies. For seeing the orderly arrangement of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: bodies, we understand that a certain incorporeal power presides over them;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: as with respect to the celestial bodies, they have a certain presiding
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: motive power. As we therefore see that our body is moved, but is no longer
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: so after death, we conceive that it was a certain incorporeal power which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: moved it. Hence, perceiving that we believe things incorporeal and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: unapparent from things apparent and corporeal, fables came to be adopted,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that we might come from things apparent to certain unapparent natures; as,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: gods, castrations of heaven, and the like, we may not rest satisfied with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the apparent meaning of such like particulars, but may proceed to the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: unapparent, and investigate the true signification. After this manner,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: therefore, looking to the nature of things, were fables employed.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

author: Taylor, Thomas

text: In the next place let us consider what the difference is between the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: fables of philosophers and poets. Each therefore has something in which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it abounds more than, and something in which it is deficient from the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: other. Thus, for instance, the poetic fable abounds in this, that we must
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: not rest satisfied with the apparent meaning, but pass on to the occult
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: truth. For who, endued with intellect, would believe that Jupiter was
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: desirous of having connection with Juno, and on the ground, without
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: waiting to go into the bed-chamber. So that the poetic fable abounds, in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: consequence of asserting such things as do not suffer us to stop at the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: apparent, but lead us to explore the occult truth. But it is defective in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: this, that it deceives those of a juvenile age. Plato therefore neglects
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: fable of this kind, and banishes Homer from his Republic; because youth
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: on hearing such fables, will not be able to distinguish what is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: allegorical from what is not.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Philosophical fables, on the contrary, do not injure those that go no
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: further than the apparent meaning. Thus, for instance, they assert that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: there are punishments and rivers under the earth: and if we adhere to the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: literal meaning of these we shall not be injured. But they are deficient
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in this, that as their apparent signification does not injure, we often
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: content ourselves with this, and do not explore the latent truth. We may
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: also say that philosophic fables look to the enemies of the soul. For if
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: we were entirely intellect alone, and had no connection with phantasy, we
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: should not require fables, in consequence of always associating with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: intellectual natures. If again, we were entirely irrational, and lived
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: according to the phantasy, and had no other energy than this, it would be
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: requisite that the whole of our life should be fabulous. Since, however,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: we possess intellect, opinion, and phantasy, demonstrations are given
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with a view to intellect; and hence Plato says that if you are willing to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: energize according to intellect, you will have demonstrations bound with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: adamantine chains; if according to opinion, you will have the testimony
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of renowned persons; and if according to the phantasy, you have fables by
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which it is excited; so that from all these you will derive advantage.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Plato therefore rejects the more tragical mode of mythologizing of the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: ancient poets, who thought proper to establish an arcane theology
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: respecting the gods, and on this account devised wanderings, castrations,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: battles and lacerations of the gods, and many other such symbols of the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: truth about divine natures which this theology conceals;--this mode he
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: rejects, and asserts that it is in every respect most foreign from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: erudition. But he considers those mythological discourses about the gods
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: as more persuasive and more adapted to truth, which assert that a divine
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: nature is the cause of all good, but of no evil, and that it is void of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: all mutation, comprehending in itself the fountain of truth, but never
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: becoming the cause of any deception to others. For such types of theology
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Socrates delivers in the Republic.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: All the fables therefore of Plato guarding the truth in concealment,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: have not even their externally apparent apparatus discordant with our
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: undisciplined and unperverted anticipations of divinity. But they bring
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with them an image of the mundane composition in which both the apparent
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: beauty is worthy of divinity, and a beauty more divine than this is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: established in the unapparent lives and powers of its causes.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: In the next place, that the reader may see whence and from what dialogues
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principally the theological dogmas of Plato may be collected, I shall
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: present him with the following translation of what Proclus has admirably
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: written on this subject.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: "The truth (says he) concerning the gods pervades, as I may say, through
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: all the Platonic dialogues, and in all of them conceptions of the first
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: philosophy, venerable, clear, and supernatural, are disseminated, in some
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: more obscurely, but in others more conspicuously;--conceptions which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: excite those that are in any respect able to partake of them, to the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: immaterial and separate essence of the gods. And as in each part of the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: universe and in nature itself, the demiurgus of all which the world
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: contains established resemblances of the unknown essence of the gods,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that all things might be converted to divinity through their alliance
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with it, in like manner I am of opinion, that the divine intellect of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Plato weaves conceptions about the gods with all its progeny, and leaves
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: nothing deprived of the mention of divinity, that from the whole of its
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: offspring a reminiscence of total natures may be obtained, and imparted
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to the genuine lovers of divine concerns.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: "But if it be requisite to lay before the reader those dialogues out of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: many which principally unfold to us the mystic discipline about the gods,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: I shall not err in ranking among this number the Phaedo and Phaedrus, the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Banquet and the Philebus, and together with these the Sophista and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Politicus, the Cratylus and the Timaeus. For all these are full through
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the whole of themselves, as I may say, of the divine science of Plato.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: But I should place in the second rank after these, the fable in the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Gorgias, and that in the Protagoras, likewise the assertions about the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: providence of the gods in the Laws, and such things as are delivered
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: about the Fates, or the mother of the Fates, or the circulations of the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: universe, in the tenth book of the Republic. Again you may, if you
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: please, place in the third rank those Epistles through which we may be
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: able to arrive at the science about divine natures. For in these, mention
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is made of the three kings; and many other divine dogmas worthy the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Platonic theory are delivered. It is necessary therefore, regarding
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: these, to explore in them each order of the gods.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Thus from the Philebus, we may receive the science respecting the one
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: good, and the two first principles of things (bound and infinity) together
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with the triad subsisting from these. For you will find all these
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: distinctly delivered to us by Plato in that dialogue. But from the Timaeus
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: you may obtain the theory about intelligibles, a divine narration about the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the celestial circulations. From the Politicus you may obtain the theory of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the fabrication in the heavens, of the periods of the universe, and of the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: intellectual causes of those periods. But from the Sophista you may learn
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the whole sublunary generation, and the idiom of the gods who are allotted
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the sublunary region, and preside over its generations and corruptions. And
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with respect to each of the gods, we may obtain many sacred conceptions
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: from the Banquet, many from the Cratylus, and many from the Phaedo. For in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: each of these dialogues more or less mention is made of divine names, from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which it is easy for those who are exorcised in divine concerns to discover
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: by a reasoning process the idioms of each.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: "It is necessary, however, to evince that each of the dogmas accords with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Platonic principles and the mystic traditions of theologists. For all the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: gods, but Plato in the second place receiving an all-perfect science of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the divinities from the Pythagoric and Orphic writings. For in the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and infinity) to the Pythagoreans, he calls them men dwelling with the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: gods, and truly blessed. Philolaus, therefore, the Pythagorean, has left
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: for us in writing admirable conceptions about these principles,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: celebrating their common progression into beings, and their separate
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: fabrication. Again, in the Timaeus, endeavouring to teach us about the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the sons of the gods, and makes them the fathers of the truth about these
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: divinities. And lastly, he delivers the orders of the sublunary gods
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: proceeding from wholes, according to the progression delivered by
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: theologists of the intellectual kings. Further still, in the Cratylus he
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: follows the traditions of theologists respecting the order of the divine
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the triadic hypostases of the demiurgi. And, in short, he every where
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: discourses concerning the gods agreeably to the principles of theologists;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: rejecting indeed the tragical part of mythological fiction, but establishing
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: first hypotheses in common with the authors of fables.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: "Perhaps, however, some one may here object to us, that we do not in a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: dialogues, as if we were studious of collecting many things into one
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: mixture, instead of deriving them all from one and the same fountain. For
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

text: things, and how in the generations of the gods, the orders between the one,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and all-perfect number, are filled up, we shall be unable to evince.

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: subsistence, and have a distinct being of their own, are nevertheless
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: comprehended, though in a different manner, in their producing whole.

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

text: abounds with much of the probable, but not of the demonstrative. Besides,

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: phantasy, or that power which perceives every thing accompanied with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: figure and interval; and on this account it may be called a figured
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: intelligence ([Greek: morphotike noesis]). This power, as Jamblichus
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: beautifully observes, groups upon, as it were, and fashions all the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: powers of the soul; exciting in opinion the illuminations from the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: senses, and fixing in that life which is extended with body, the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: impressions which descend from intellect. Hence, slays Proclus, it folds
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself about the indivisibility of true intellect, conforms itself to all
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: formless species, and becomes perfectly every thing, from which the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: dianoetic power and our indivisible reason consists. Hence too, it is all
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: things passively which intellect is impassively, and on this account
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Aristotle calls it passive intellect. Under this subsist anger and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: desire, the former resembling a raging lion, and the latter a many-headed
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: beast; and the whole is bounded by sense, which is nothing more than a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: passive perception of things, and on this account is justly said by
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Plato, to be rather passion than knowledge; since the former of these is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: characterized by alertness, and the latter by energy.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Further still, in order that the union of the soul with this gross
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: terrestrial body may be effected in a becoming manner, two vehicles,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: according to Plato, are necessary as media, one of which is ethereal, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the other aerial, and of these, the ethereal vehicle is simple and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: immaterial, but the aerial, simple and material; and this dense earthly
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: body is composite and material.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The soul thus subsisting as a medium between natures impartible
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and such as are divided about bodies, it produces and constitutes the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: latter of these; but establishes in itself the prior causes from which it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: proceeds. Hence it previously receives, after the manner of an exemplar,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the natures to which it is prior as their cause; but it possesses through
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: participation, and as the blossoms of first natures, the causes of its
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: subsistence. Hence it contains in its essence immaterial forms of things
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: material, incorporeal of such as are corporeal, and extended of such as
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: are distinguished by interval. But it contains intelligibles after the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: manner of an image, and receives partibly their impartible forms, such
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: as are uniform variously, and such as are immovable, according to a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: self-motive condition. Soul therefore is all things, and is elegantly
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: said by Olympiodorus to be an omniform statue ([Greek: pammorphon
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: agalma]): for it contains such things as are first through participation,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: but such as are posterior to its nature, after the manner of an exemplar.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: As, too, it is always moved; and this always is not eternal, but
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: temporal, for that which is properly eternal, and such is intellect, is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: perfectly stable, and has no transitive energies, hence it is necessary
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that its motions should be periodic. For motion is a certain mutation
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: from some things into others. And beings are terminated by multitudes and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: magnitudes. These therefore being terminated, there can neither be an
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: infinite mutation, according to a right line, nor can that which is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: always moved proceed according to a finished progression. Hence that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which is always moved will proceed from the same to the same; and will
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: thus form a periodic motion. Hence, too, the human, and this also is true
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of every mundane soul, uses periods and restitutions of its proper life.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: For, in consequence of being measured by time, it energizes transitively,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and possesses a proper motion. But every thing which is moved perpetually
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and participates of time, revolves periodically and proceeds from the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: same to the same. And hence the soul, from possessing motion, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: energizing according to time, will both possess periods of motion and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: restitutions to its pristine state.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Again, as the human soul, according to Plato, ranks among the number of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: those souls that sometimes follow the mundane divinities, in consequence
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of subsisting immediately after daemons and heroes, the perpetual
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: attendants of the gods, hence it possesses a power of descending
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: infinitely into generation, or the sublunary region, and of ascending
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: from generation to real being. For since it does not reside with divinity
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: through an infinite time, neither will it be conversant with bodies
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: through the whole succeeding time. For that which has no temporal
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: beginning, both according to Plato and Aristotle, cannot have an end; and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that which has no end, is necessarily without a beginning. It remains,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: therefore, that every soul must perform periods, both of ascensions from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: generation, and of descensions into generation; and that this will never
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: fail, through an infinite time.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: From all this it follows that the soul, while an inhabitant of earth, is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in a fallen condition, an apostate from deity, an exile from the orb of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: light. Hence Plato, in the 7th book of his Republic, considering our life
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with reference to erudition and the want of it, assimilates us to men in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: a subterranean cavern, who have been there confined from their childhood,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and so fettered by chains as to be only able to look before them to the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: entrance of the cave which expands to the light, but incapable through
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the chain of turning themselves round. He supposes too, that they have
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the light of a fire burning far above and behind them; and that between
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the fire and the fettered men, there is a road above, along which a low
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: wall is built. On this wall are seen men bearing utensils of every kind,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and statues in wood and stone of men and other animals. And of these men
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: some are speaking and others silent. With respect to the fettered men in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: this cave, they see nothing of themselves or another, or of what is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: carrying along, but the shadows formed by the fire falling on the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: opposite part of tho cave. He supposes too, that the opposite part of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: this prison has an echo; and that in consequence of this the fettered
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: men, when they hear any one speak, will imagine that it is nothing else
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: than the passing shadow.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Here, in the first place, as we have observed in the notes on that book,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the road above between the fire and the fettered men, indicates that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: there is a certain ascent in the cave itself from a more abject to a more
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: elevated life. By this ascent, therefore Plato signifies the contemplation
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of dianoetic objects in the mathematical disciplines. For as the shadows
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in the cave correspond to the shadows of visible objects, and visible
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: objects are the immediate images of dianoetic forms, or those ideas which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the soul essentially participates, it is evident that the objects from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which these shadows are formed must correspond to such as are dianoetic.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: It is requisite, therefore, that the dianoetic power exercising itself in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: these, should draw forth the principles of these from their latent
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: retreats, and should contemplate them not in images, but as subsisting in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: herself in impartible involution.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: In the next place he says, "that the man who is to be led from the cave
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: will more easily see what the heavens contain, and the heavens
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: themselves, by looking in the night to the light of the stars, and the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: moon, than by day looking on the sun, and the light of the sun." By this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: he signifies the contemplation of intelligibles: for the stars and their
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: light are imitations of intelligibles, so far as all of them partake of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the form of the sun, in the same manner as intelligibles are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: characterized by the nature of the good.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: After the contemplation of these, and after the eye is accustomed through
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: these to the light, as it is requisite in the visible region to see the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sun himself in the last place, in like manner, according to Plato, the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: idea of the good must be seen the last in the intelligible region. He,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: likewise divinely adds, that it is scarcely to be seen; for we can only
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: be conjoined with it through the intelligible, in the vestibule of which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it is beheld by the ascending soul.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: In short, the cold, according to Plato, can only be restored while on
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: earth to the divine likeness, which she abandoned by her descent, and be
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: able after death to reascend to the intelligible world, by the exercise
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of the cathartic and theoretic virtues; the former purifying her from the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: defilements of a mortal nature, and the latter elevating her to the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: vision of true being: for thus, as Plato says in the Timaeus, "the soul
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: becoming sane and entire, will arrive at the form of her pristine habit."
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The cathartic, however, must necessarily precede the theoretic virtues;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: since it is impossible to survey truth while subject to the perturbation
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and tumult of the passions. For the rational soul subsisting as a medium
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: between intellect and the irrational nature, can then only without
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: revulsion associate with the intellect prior to herself, when she becomes
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: pure from copassivity with inferior natures. By the cathartic virtues,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: therefore, we become sane, in consequence of being liberated from the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: passions as diseases; but we become entire by the reassumption of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: intellect and science as of our proper parts; and this is effected by
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: contemplative truth. Plato also clearly teaches us that our apostacy from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: better natures is only to be healed by a flight from hence, when he
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: defines in his Theaetetus philosophy to be a flight from terrestrial
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: evils: for he evinces by this that passions are connascent with mortals
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: alone. He likewise says in the same dialogue, "that neither can evil
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: be abolished, nor yet do they subsist with the gods, but that they
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: necessarily revolve about this terrene abode, and a mortal nature." For
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: those who are obnoxious to generation and corruption can also be affected
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in a manner contrary to nature, which is the beginning of evils. But in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the same dialogue he subjoins the mode by which our flight from evil
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is to be accomplished. "It is necessary," says he "to fly from hence
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: thither: but the flight is a similitude to divinity, as far as is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: possible to man; and this similitude consists in becoming just and holy
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in conjunction with intellectual prudence." For it is necessary that he
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: who wishes to run from evils, should in the first place turn away from a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: mortal nature; since it is not possible for those who are mingled with it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to avoid being filled with its attendant evils. As therefore, through our
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: flight from divinity, and the defluction of those wings which elevate us
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: on high, we fell into this mortal abode, and thus became connected with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: evils, so by abandoning passivity with a mortal nature, and by the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: germination of the virtues, as of certain wings, we return to the abode
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of pure and true good, and to the possession of divine felicity. For the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: essence of many subsisting as a medium between daemoniacal natures, who
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: always have an intellectual knowledge of divinity, and those beings who
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: are never adapted by nature to understand him, it ascends to the former
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and descends to the latter, through the possession and desertion of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: intellect. For it becomes familiar both with the divine and brutal
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: likeness, through the amphibious condition of its nature.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: When the soul therefore has recovered her pristine perfection in as great
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: a degree as is possible, while she is an inhabitant of earth by the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: exercise of the cathartic and theoretic virtues, she returns after death,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: as he says in the Timaeus, to her kindred star, from which she fell, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: enjoys a blessed life. Then, too, as he says in the Phaedrus, being
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: winged, she governs the world in conjunction with the gods. And this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: indeed is the most beautiful end of her labors. This is what he calls in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the Phaedo, a great contest and a mighty hope. This is the most perfect
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: fruit of philosophy to familiarize and lead her back to things truly
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: beautiful, to liberate her from this terrene abode as from a certain
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: subterranean cavern of material life, elevate her to ethereal splendors,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and place her in the islands of the blessed.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: From this account of the human soul, that most important Platonic dogma
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: necessarily follows, that our soul essentially contains all knowledge,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and that whatever knowledge she acquires in the present life, is in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: reality nothing more than a recovery of what a he once possessed. This
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: recovery is very properly called by Plato reminiscence, not as being
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: attended with actual recollection in the present life, but as being an
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: actual repossession of what the soul had lost through her oblivious union
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with the body. Alluding to this essential knowledge of the soul, which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: discipline evocates from its dormant retreats, Plato says in the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Sophista, "that we know all things as in a dream, and are again ignorant
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of them, according to vigilant perception." Hence too, as Proclus well
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: observes, it is evident that the soul does not collect her knowledge from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sensibles, nor from things partial and divisible discover the whole and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the one. For it is not proper to think that things which have in no
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: respect a real subsistence, should be the leading causes of knowledge to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the soul; and that things which oppose each other and are ambiguous,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: should precede science which has a sameness of subsistence; nor that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: things which are variously mutable, should be generative of reasons which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: are established in unity; nor that things indefinite should be the causes
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of definite intelligence. It is not fit, therefore, that the truth of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: things eternal should be received from the many, nor the discrimination
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of universals from sensibles, nor a judgment respecting what is good from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: irrational natures; but it is requisite that the soul entering within
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: herself, should investigate herself the true and the good, and the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: eternal reasons of things.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: We have said that discipline awakens the dormant knowledge of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the soul; and Plato considered this as particularly effected by the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: mathematical discipline. Hence, he asserts of theoretic arithmetic that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it imparts no small aid to our ascent to real being, and that it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: liberates us from the wandering and ignorance about a sensible nature.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Geometry too is considered by him as most instrumental to the knowledge
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of the good, when it is not pursued for the sake of practical purposes,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: but as the means of ascent to an intelligible essence. Astronomy also is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: useful for the purpose of investigating the fabricator of all things,

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Dialectic, however, or the vertex of the mathematical sciences,

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: same with what Aristotle calls the first philosophy and wisdom, I have
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: largely spoken in the introduction and notes to the Parmenides. Suffice
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it therefore to observe in this place, that dialectic differs from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas
