title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: does he accuse it as ignorant of its own principles, but considers it as
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: receiving these from the master science dialectic, and that possessing
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: them without any demonstration, it demonstrates from these its consequent
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: propositions.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Hence Socrates, in the Republic, speaking of the power of dialectic,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: says that it surrounds all disciplines like a defensive enclosure, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: elevates those that use it to the good itself, and the first unities;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that it purifies the eye of the soul; establishes itself in true beings,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and, the one principle of all things, and ends at last in that which is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: no longer hypothetical. The power of dialectic, therefore, being thus
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: great, and the ends of this path so mighty, it must by no means be
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: confounded with arguments which are alone conversant with opinion: for
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the former is the guardian of sciences, and the passage to it is through
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: these, but the latter is perfectly destitute of disciplinative science.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: To which we may add, that the method of reasoning which is founded in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: opinion, regards only that which is apparent; but the dialectic method
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: endeavors to arrive at the one itself, always employing for this purpose
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: steps of ascent, and at last beautifully ends in the nature of the good.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Very different therefore is it from the merely logical method, which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: presides over the demonstrative phantasy, is of a secondary nature, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is alone pleased with contentious discussions. For the dialectic of Plato
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: for the most part employs divisions and analyses as primary sciences, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: as imitating the progression of beings from the one, and their conversion
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to it again. It likewise sometimes uses definitions and demonstrations,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and prior to these the definitive method, and the divisive prior to this.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: On the contrary, the merely logical method, which is solely conversant
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with opinion, is deprived of the incontrovertible reasonings of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: demonstration.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The following is a specimen of the analytical method of Plato's dialectic.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Of analysis there are three species. For one is an ascent from sensibles
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to the first intelligibles; a second is an ascent through things
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: demonstrated and subdemonstrated, to undemonstrated and immediate
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: propositions; and a third proceeds from hypothesis to unhypothetical
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principles. Of the first of these species, Plato has given a most
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: admirable specimen in the speech of Diotima in the Banquet. For there he
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: ascends from the beauty about bodies to the beauty in souls; from this to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the beauty in right disciplines; from this again to the beauty in laws;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: from the beauty in laws to the ample sea of beauty (Greek: to polu pelagos
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: tou kalou); and thus proceeding he at length arrives at the beautiful
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The second species of analysis is as follows: It is necessary to make the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: thing investigated the subject of hypothesis; to survey such things as
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: are prior to it; and to demonstrate these from things posterior,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: ascending to such as are prior, till we arrive at the first thing and to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which we give our assent. But beginning from this, we descend
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: synthetically to the thing investigated. Of this species, the following
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is an example from the Phaedrus of Plato. It is inquired if the soul is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: immortal; and this being hypothetically admitted, it is inquired in the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: next place if it is always moved. This being demonstrated, the next
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: inquiry is if that which is always moved, is self-moved; and this again
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: being demonstrated, it is considered whether that which is self-moved is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the principle of motion, and afterwards if the principle is unbegotten.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: This then being admitted as a thing acknowledged, and likewise that what
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is begotten is incorruptible, the demonstration of the thing proposed is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: thus collected. If there is a principle, it is unbegotten and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: incorruptible. That which is self-moved is the principle of motion. Soul
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is self-moved. Soul therefore (i.e. the rational soul) is incorruptible,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: unbegotten, and immortal.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Of the third species of analysis, which proceeds from the hypothetical to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that which is unhypothetical, Plato has given a most beautiful specimen
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in the first hypothesis of his Parmenides. For here, taking for his
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: hypothesis that the one is, he proceeds through an orderly series of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: negations, which are not privative of their subjects, but generative of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: things which are as it were, their opposites, till he at length takes
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: away the hypothesis that the one is. For he denies of it all discourse
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and every appellation. And thus evidently denies of it not only that it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is, but even negation. For all things are posterior to the one; viz.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: things known, knowledge, and the instruments of knowledge. And thus,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: beginning from the hypothetical, he ends in that which is unhypothetical,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and truly ineffable.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Having taken a general survey, both of the great world and the microcosm
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: man, I shall close this account of the principal dogmas of Plato, with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the outlines of his doctrine concerning Providence and Fate, as it is a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: subject of the greatest importance, and the difficulties in which it is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: involved are happily removed by that prince of philosophers.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: In the first place, therefore, Providence, according to common
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: conceptions, is the cause of good to the subjects of its care; and Fate
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is the cause of a certain connection to generated natures. This being
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: admitted, let us consider what the things are which are connected. Of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: beings, therefore, some have their essence in eternity, and others in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: time. But by beings whose essence is in eternity, I mean those whose
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: energy as well as their essence is eternal; and by beings essentially
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: temporal, those whose essence is always in generation, or becoming to be,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: though this should take place in an infinite time. The media between
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: these two extremes are natures which, in a certain respect, have an
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: essence permanent and better than generation, or a flowing subsistence,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: but whose energy is measured by time. For it is necessary that every
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: procession from things first to last should be effected through media.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The medium, therefore, between these two extremes, must either be that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which has an eternal essence, but any energy indigent of time, or, on the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: contrary, that which has a temporal essence, but an eternal energy. It is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: impossible, however, for the latter of these to have any subsistence; for
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: if this were admitted, energy would be prior to essence. The medium,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: therefore, must be that whose essence is eternal, but energy temporal.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: And the three orders which compose this first middle and last are, the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: intellectual, psychical (or that pertaining to soul), and corporeal. For
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: from what has been already said by us concerning the gradation of beings,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it is evident that the intellectual order is established in eternity,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: both in essence and energy; that the corporeal order is always in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: generation, or advancing to being, and this either in an infinite time,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: or in a part of time; and that the psychical is indeed eternal in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: essence, but temporal in energy. Where then shall we rank things which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: being distributed either in places or times, have a certain coordination
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and sympathy with each other through connection? It is evident that they
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: must be ranked among altermotive and corporeal natures. For of things
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which subsist beyond the order of bodies, some are better both than place
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and time; and others, though they energize according to time, appear to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: be entirely pure from any connection with place.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Hence things which are governed and connected by Fate are entirely
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: altermotive and corporeal. If this then is demonstrated, it is manifest
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that admitting Fate to be a cause of connection, we must assert that it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: presides over altermotive and corporeal natures. If, therefore, we look
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to that which is the proximate cause of bodies, and thorough which also
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: altermotive beings are moved, breathe, and are held together, we shall
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: find that this is nature, the energies of which are to generate, nourish,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and increase. If, therefore, this power not only subsists in us, and all
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: other animals and plants, but prior to partial bodies there is, by a much
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: greater necessity, one nature of the world which comprehends and is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: motive of all bodies; it follows that nature must be the cause of things
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: connected, and that in this we must investigate Fate. Hence, Fate is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: nature, or that incorporeal power which is the one life of the world,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: presiding over bodies, moving all things according to time, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: connecting the motions of things that, by places and times, are distant
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: from each other. It is likewise the cause of the mutual sympathy of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: mortal natures, and of their conjunction with such as are eternal. For
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the nature which is in us, binds and connects all the parts of our body,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of which also it is a certain Fate. And as in our body some parts have a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principal subsistence, and others are less principal, and the latter are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: consequent to the former, so in the universe, the generations of the less
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: principal parts are consequent to the motions of the more principal, viz.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the sublunary generations to the periods of the celestial bodies; and the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: circle of the former is the image of the latter.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Hence it is not difficult to see that Providence is deity itself, the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: fountain of all good. For whence can good be imparted, to all things, but
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: from divinity? So that no other cause of good but deity is, as Plato
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: says, to be assigned. And, in the next place, as this cause is superior
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to all intelligible and sensible natures, it is consequently superior to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Fate. Whatever too is subject to Fate, is also under the dominion of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Providence; having its connection indeed from Fate, but deriving the good
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which it possesses from Providence. But again, not all things that are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: under the dominion of Providence are indigent of Fate; for intelligibles
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: are exempt from its sway. Fate therefore is profoundly conversant with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: corporeal natures; since connection introduces time and corporeal motion.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Hence Plato, looking to this, says in the Timaeus, that the world is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: mingled from intellect and necessity, the former ruling over the latter.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: For by necessity here he means the motive cause of bodies, which in other
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: places he calls Fate. And this with great propriety; since every body is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: compelled to do whatever it does, and to suffer whatever it suffers; to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: heat or to be heated, to impart or to receive cold. But the elective
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: power is unknown to a corporeal nature; so that the necessary and the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: nonelective may be said to be the peculiarities of bodies.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: As there are two genera of things, therefore, the intelligible and the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sensible, so likewise there are two kingdoms of these; that of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Providence, upwards, which reigns over intelligibles and sensibles, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that of Fate downwards, which reigns over sensibles only. Providence
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: likewise differs from Fate in the same manner as deity from that which is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: divine indeed, but participation, and not primarily. For in other things
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: we see that which has a primary subsistence, and that which subsists
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: according to participation. Thus the light which subsists in the orb of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the sun is primary light, and that which is in the air, according to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: participation; the latter being derived from the former. And life is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: primarily in the soul, but secondarily in the body. Thus also, according
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to Plato, Providence is deity, but Fate is something divine, and not a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: god: for it depends upon Providence, of which it is as it were the image.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: As Providence too is to intelligibles, so is Fate to sensibles. And,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: alternately, as Providence is to Fate, so are intelligibles to sensibles.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: But intelligibles are the first of beings, and from these others derive
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: becomes manifest, that when it energizes according to its nature, it is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: rectitude. And hence the elective will be the same with that which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and mortal natures: for each of these is void of that two-fold inclination;

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The following arguments, however, may perhaps awaken some few of these
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: who are less lethargic than the rest, from the sleep of sense, and enable
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: plunged, and gain a glimpse of this most weighty truth, that there is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: resemblance, and another life, of which this is but the flying mockery.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: My present discourse therefore is addressed to those who consider
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: experiment as the only solid criterion of truth. In the first place then,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: these men appear to be ignorant of the invariable laws of demonstration
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: properly so called, and that the necessary requisites of all
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: demonstrative propositions are these: that they exist as causes, are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: primary, more excellent, peculiar, true, and known than the conclusions.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: For every demonstration not only consists of principles prior to others,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: but of such as are eminently first; since if the assumed propositions may
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: be demonstrated by other assumptions, such propositions may indeed
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: appear prior to the conclusions, but are by no means entitled to the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: appellation of first. Others, on the contrary, which require no
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: demonstration, but are of themselves manifest, are deservedly esteemed
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the first, the truest, and the best. Such indemonstrable truths were
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: called by the ancients axioms from their majesty and authority, as the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: assumptions which constitute demonstrative syllogisms derive all their
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: force and efficacy from these.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: In the next place, they seem not to be sufficiently aware, that universal
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is better than partial demonstration. For that demonstration is the more
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: excellent which is derived from the better cause; but a universal is more
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: extended and excellent than a partial cause; since the arduous
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: investigation of the why in any subject is only stopped by the arrival at
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: universals. Thus if we desire to know why the outward angles of a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: triangle are equal to four right angles, and it is answered, Because the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: triangle is isosceles; we again ask, but why Because isosceles? And if it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: be replied, Because it is a triangle; we may again inquire, But why
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: because a triangle? To which we finally answer, because a triangle is a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: right-lined figure. And here our inquiry rests at that universal idea,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which embraces every preceding particular one, and is contained in no
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: other more general and comprehensive than itself. Add too, that the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: demonstration of particulars is almost the demonstration of infinites; of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: universals the demonstration of finites; and of infinites there can be no
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: science. That demonstration likewise is the best which furnishes the mind
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with the most ample knowledge; and this is, alone, the province of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: universals. We may also add, that he who knows universals knows
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: particulars likewise in capacity; but we can not infer that he who has
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the best knowledge of particulars, knows any thing of universals. And
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: lastly, that which is universal is the object of intellect and reason;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: but particulars are coordinated to the perceptions of sense.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: But here perhaps the experimentalist will say, admitting all this to be
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: true, yet we no otherwise obtain a perception of these universals than by
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: an induction of particulars, and abstraction from sensibles. To this, I
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: answer that the universal which is the proper object of science, is not
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: subservient to its existence than an exciting cause. For if scientific
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: In short, if the words all and every, with which every page of theoretic
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: mathematics is full, mean what they are conceived by all men to mean, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Hence it will follow that induction is no otherwise subservient to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: science, than as it produces credibility in axioms and petitions; and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: this by exciting the universal conception of these latent in the soul.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The particulars, therefore, of which an induction is made in order to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: produce science, must be so simple, that they may be immediately
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and therefore never can be sources of science truly so called.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Of this, however, the man of experiment appears to be totally ignorant,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and in consequence of this, he is likewise ignorant that parts can only

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: observed, from comprehending in itself the parts which it produces, is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: called a whole prior to parts. As he, therefore, would by no means merit
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Thus much for the manner in which the dialogues of Plato are severally
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: composed, and the cast of genius given them in their composition. The
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: form under which they appear, or the external character that marks them,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is of three sorts: either purely dramatic, like the dialogue of tragedy
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: or comedy; or purely narrative, where a former conversation is supposed
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to be committed to writing, and communicated to some absent friend; or of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the mixed kind, like a narration in dramatic poems, where is recited, to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: some person present, the story of things past.

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Having thus divided the dialogues of Plato, in respect of that inward
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: form or composition, which creates their genius; and again, with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: reference to that outward form, which marks them, like flowers and other
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: vegetables, with a certain character; we are further to make a division
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of them, with regard to their subject and their design; beginning with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: their design, or end, because for the sake of this are all the subjects
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: chosen. The end of all the writings of Plato is that, which is the end of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: all true philosophy or wisdom, the perfection and the happiness of man.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Man therefore is the general subject; and the first business of philosophy
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: must be to inquire what is that being called man, who is to be made happy;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and what is his nature, in the perfection of which is placed his happiness.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: As however, in the preceding part of this Introduction, we have endeavored
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to give the outlines of Plato's doctrine concerning man, it is unnecessary
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in this place to say any thing further on that subject.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The dialogues of Plato, therefore, with respect to their subjects, may be
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: divided into the speculative, the practical, and such as are of a mixed
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: nature. The subjects of these last are either general, comprehending both
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the others; or differential, distinguishing them. The general subject are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: either fundamental, or final: those of the fundamental kind are philosophy,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: human nature, the soul of man; of the final kind are love, beauty, good.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The differential regard knowledge, as it stands related to practice; in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which are considered two questions: one of which is, whether virtue is to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: he taught; the other is, whether error in the will depends on error in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the judgment. The subjects of the speculative dialogues relate either to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: words, or to things. Of the former sort are etymology, sophistry, rhetoric,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: poetry; of the latter sort are science, true being, the principles of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: mind, outward nature. The practical subjects relate either to private
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: conduct, and the government of the mind over the whole man; or to his
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: duty towards others in his several relations; or to the government of a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: civil state, and the public conduct of a whole people. Under these three
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: heads rank in order the particular subjects practical; virtue in general,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sanctity, temperance, fortitude, justice, friendship, patriotism, piety;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the ruling mind in a civil government, the frame and order of a state,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: law in general, and lastly, those rules of government and of public
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: conduct, the civil laws.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Thus, for the sake of giving the reader a scientific, that is a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: comprehensive, and at the same time a distinct view of Plato's writings,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: we have attempted to exhibit to him, their just and natural distinctions;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: whether he chooses to consider them with regard to their inward form or
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: essence, their outward form or appearance, their matter; or their end:
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that is, in those more familiar terms, we have used in this Synopsis,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: their genius, their character, their subject, and their design.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: And here it is requisite to observe, that as it is the characteristic of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the highest good to be universally beneficial, though some things are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: benefitted by it more and others less, in consequence of their greater or
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: so largely stamped with the characters of sovereign good, that they are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: calculated to benefit in a certain degree even those who are incapable
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of penetrating their profundity. They can tame a savage sophist, like
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: political, who will never arrive at theoretic virtue; and, in short, like
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: their recipients, they purify, irradiate, and exalt.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: After this general view of the dialogues of Plato, let us in the next
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: place consider their preambles, the digressions with which they abound,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: design of the dialogues which they accompany. Thus the prefatory part of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the Timaeus unfolds, in images agreeably to the Pythagoric custom, the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: discussion of ideas, is in fact merely a preamble to the second part,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: or the speculation of the one; to which however it is essentially
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: preparatory. Hence, as Plutarch says, when he speaks of Plato's dialogue
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: on the Atlantic island: These preambles are superb gates and magnificent
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: courts with which he purposely embellishes his great edifices, that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: nothing may be wanting to their beauty, and that all may be equally
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: splendid. He acts, as Dacier well observes, like a great prince, who,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: when he builds a sumptuous palace, adorns (in the language of Pindar) the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: announce all that grandeur which afterwards presents itself to the view.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: With respect to the frequent digressions in his dialogues, these also,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: when accurately examined, will be found to be no less subservient to the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: leading design of the dialogues in which they are introduced; at the same
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: time that they afford a pleasing relaxation to the mind from the labor of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: severe investigation. Hence Plato, by the most happy and enchanting art,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: contrives to lead the reader to the temple of Truth through the delightful
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: groves and valleys of the Graces. In short, this circuitous course, when
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: attentively considered, will be found to be the shortest road by which he
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: could conduct the reader to the desired end: for in accomplishing this it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is necessary to regard not that road, which is most straight in the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: nature of things, or abstractedly considered, but that which is most
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: direct in the progressions of human understanding.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: With respect to the style of Plato, though it forms in reality the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: most inconsiderable part of the merit of his writings, style in all
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: philosophical works being the last thing that should be attended to, yet
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: even in this Plato may contend for the palm of excellence with the most
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: renowned masters of diction. Hence we find that his style was the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: admiration of the finest writers of antiquity. According to Ammianus,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Jupiter himself would not speak otherwise, if he were to converse in the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Attic tongue. Aristotle considered his style as a medium between poetry
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and prose. Cicero no less praises him for the excellence of his diction
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: than the profundity of his conceptions; and Longinus calls him with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: respect to his language, the rival of Homer. Hence he is considered by
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: this prince of critics, as deriving into himself abundant streams from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the Homeric fountain, and is compared by him, in his rivalship of Homer,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to a new antagonist who enters the lists against one that is already the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: object of universal admiration.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Notwithstanding this praise, however, Plato has been accused, as Longinus
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: informs us, of being frequently hurried away as by a certain Bacchic fury
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of words to immoderate and unpleasant metaphors, and an allegoric
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: magnificence of diction. Longinus excuses this by saying that whatever
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: naturally excels in magnitude possesses very little of purity. For that,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: says he, which is in every respect accurate is in danger of littleness.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: moderate genius, because they never encounter danger, nor aspire after
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the summit of excellence, are for the most part without error and remain
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in security; but that great things become insecure through their magnitude?"
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Indeed it appears to me, that whenever this exuberance, this Bacchic
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: fury, occurs in the diction of Plato, it is owing to the magnitude of the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: inspiring influence of deity with which he is then replete. For that he
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sometimes wrote from divine inspiration is evident from his own confession
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in the Phaedrus, a great part of which is not so much like an orderly
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: discourse as a dithyrambic poem. Such a style therefore, as it is the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: progeny of divine mania, which, as Plato justly observes, is better than
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: all human prudence, spontaneously adapts itself to its producing cause,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: imitates a supernatural power as far as this can be effected by words,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and thus necessarily becomes magnificent, vehement, and exuberant; for
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: such are the characteristics of its source. All judges of composition
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: however, both ancient and modern, are agreed that his style is in general
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: graceful and pure; and that it is sublime without being impetuous and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

text: [27] The reader will see, from the notes on Plato's dialogues, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of that philosopher possesses an accuracy which is not to be found in any
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Having thus considered the philosophy of Plato, given a general view of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to close this Introduction.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: As no accurate and scientific arrangement then of these dialogues has
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

text: In the next place, it is necessary to speak concerning the qualifications
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of the Greek tongue, however great that knowledge may be, is alone
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of the elements of geometry, merely because he can read him in the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: original. Those who entertain such an idle opinion, would do well to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: By a legitimate student, then, of the Platonic philosophy, I mean one
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: who, both from nature and education, is properly qualified for such
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: an arduous undertaking; that is one who possesses a naturally good
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: disposition; is sagacious and acute, and is inflamed with an ardent
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: desire for the acquisition of wisdom and truth; who from his childhood
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: has been well instructed in the mathematical disciplines; who, besides
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: this, has spent whole days, and frequently the greater part of the night,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in profound meditation; and, like one triumphantly sailing over a raging
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sea, or skillfully piercing through an army of foes, has successfully
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: encountered an hostile multitude of doubts;--in short, who has never
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: considered wisdom as a thing of trifling estimation and easy access, but
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: as that which cannot be obtained without the most generous and severe
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: endurance, and the intrinsic worth of which surpasses all corporeal good,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: far more than the ocean the fleeting bubble which floats on its surface.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: their sole employment, and the pursuit of wisdom but at best a secondary
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: thing, who expect to be wise by desultory application for an hour or two
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: distempered imagination, or the ebullitions of fanatical faith.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: But all this is by no means wonderful, if we consider that two-fold
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: ignorance is the disease of the many. For they are not only ignorant with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: respect to the sublimest knowledge, but they are even ignorant of their
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: ignorance. Hence they never suspect their want of understanding, but
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: immediately reject a doctrine which appears at first sight absurd,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: because it is too splendid for their bat-like eyes to behold. Or if they
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: even yield their assent to its truth, their very assent is the result of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the same most dreadful disease of the soul. For they will fancy, says
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Plato, that they understand the highest truths, when the very contrary is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: really the case. I earnestly therefore entreat men of this description,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: not to meddle with any of the profound speculations of the Platonic
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: philosophy, for it is more dangerous to urge them to such an employment,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: than to advise them to follow their sordid avocations with unwearied
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: assiduity, and toil for wealth with increasing alacrity and vigor; as
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: they will by this means give free scope to the base habits of their soul,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and sooner suffer that punishment which in such as these must always
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: precede mental illumination, and be the inevitable consequence of guilt.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the mud, and cause the pure water to become defiled. The woods of such,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: as the same author beautifully observes, (that is the irrational or
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: through preparatory disciplines, and the political virtues), and reason
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: can be planted in these savage haunts.

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Let not such then presume to explore the regions of Platonic philosophy.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the effeminate and the timid, by the slave of passion and the dupe of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: opinion, by the lover of sense and the despiser of truth. The dangers and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: by the deadly melody of the Syren's song. To the most skillful traveler,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: who pursues the right road with an ardor which no toils can abate, with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

text: of a stormy sea of doubts.

text: EXPLANATIONS OF CERTAIN PLATONIC TERMS
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: As some apology may be thought necessary for having introduced certain
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: unusual words of Greek origin, I shall only observe, that, as all arts and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sciences have certain appropriate terms peculiar to themselves, philosophy,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which is the art of arts, and science of sciences, as being the mistress of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: both, has certainly a prior and a far superior claim to this privilege. I
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: have not, however, introduced, I believe, any of these terms without at the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: same time sufficiently explaining them; but, lest the contrary should have
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: taken place, the following explanation of all such terms as I have been
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: able to recollect, and also of common words used by Platonists in a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: peculiar sense, is subjoined for the information of the reader.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Dianoetia. This word is derived from [Greek: dianoia], or that power of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the soul which reasons scientifically, deriving the principles of its
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: reasoning from intellect. Plato is so uncommonly accurate in his diction,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that this word is very seldom used by him in any other than its primary
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: sense.
