author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The Divine, [Greek: to Theion], is being subsisting in conjunction with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the one. For all things, except the one, viz. essence, life, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: intellect, are considered by Plato as suspended from and secondary to the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: gods. For the gods do not subsist in, but prior to, these, which they
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: also produce and connect, but are not characterized by these. In many
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: places, however, Plato calls the participants of the gods by the names of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the gods. For not only the Athenian Guest in the Laws, but also Socrates
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in the Phaedrus, calls a divine soul a god. "For," says he, "all the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: horses and charioteers of the gods are good," &c. And afterwards, still
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: more clearly, he adds, "And this is the life of the gods." And not only
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: this, but he also denominates those nature gods that are always united to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the gods, and which, in conjunction with them, give completion to one
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: series. He also frequently calls daemons gods, though, according to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: essence, they are secondary to and subsist about the gods. For in the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Phaedrus, Timaeus, and other dialogues, he extends the appellation of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: gods as far as the daemons. And what is still more paradoxical than all
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: this, he does not refuse to call some men gods; as, for instance, the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Elean Guest in the Sophista. From all this, therefore, we must infer that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with respect to the word god, one thing which is thus denominated is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: simply deity; another is so according to union; a third, according to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: participation; a fourth, according to contact; and a fifth, according to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: similitude. Thus every superessential nature is primarily a god; but
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: every intellectual nature is so according to union. And again, every
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: divine soul is a god according to participation; but divine daemons are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: gods according to contact with the gods; and the souls of men obtain this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: secondary to the first deity, in the same manner as the united is to the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: one; that which is intellectual to intellect; and that which is animated
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to soul. Indeed, things more uniform and simple always precede, and the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: another, or is himself received at an entertainment. In the following
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: dialogues, therefore, wherever one of the speakers is introduced as a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Xenos, I have translated this word guest, as being more conformable to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the genius of Plato's dialogues, which may be justly called rich mental
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: banquets, and consequently the speakers in them may be considered as so
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: many guests. Hence in the Timaeus, the persons of that dialogue are
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: expressly spoken of as guests.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Hyparxis, [Greek: uparxis]. The first principle or foundation, as it
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: were, of the essence of a thing. Hence also, it is the summit of essence.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Idiom, [Greek: Idioma]. The characteristic peculiarity of a thing.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The Immortal, [Greek: To athanaton]. According to Plato, there are many
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: orders of immortality, pervading from on high to the last of things; and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the ultimate echo, as it were, of immorality is seen in the perpetuity of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the mundane wholes, which according to the doctrine of the Elean Guest in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the Politicus, they participate from the Father of the universe. For both
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the being and the life of every body depend on another cause; since body
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is not itself naturally adapted to connect, or adorn, or preserve itself.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: But the immortality of partial souls, such as ours, is more manifest and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: more perfect than this of the perpetual bodies in the universe; as is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: evident from the many demonstrations which are given of it in the Phaedo,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and in the 10th book of the Republic. For the immortality of partial
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: souls has a more principal subsistence, as possessing in itself the cause
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of eternal permanency. But prior to both these is the immortality of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: daemons; for these neither verge to mortality, nor are they filled with
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the nature of things which are generated and corrupted. More venerable,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: however, than these, and essentially transcending them, is the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: immortality of divine souls, which are primarily self-motive, and contain
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the fountains and principles of the life which is attributed about
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: bodies, and through which bodies participate of renewed immortality. And
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: prior to all these is the immortality of the gods: for Diotima in the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Banquet does not ascribe an immortality of this kind to demons. Hence
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: such an immortality as this is separate and exempt from wholes. For,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: together with the immortality of the gods, eternity subsists, which is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the fountain of all immortality and life, as well that life which is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: perpetual, as that which is dissipated into nonentity. In short,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: therefore, the divine immortal is that which is generative and connective
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of perpetual life. For it is not immortal, as participating of life, but
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: as supplying divine life, and deifying life itself.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Imparticipable, [Greek: To amethekton]. That which is not consubsistent
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with an inferior nature. Thus imparticipable intellect is an intellect
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which is not consubsistent with soul.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Intellectual Projection, [Greek: noera epibole]. As the perception of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: intellect is immediate, being a darting forth, as it were, directly to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: its proper objects, this direct intuition is expressed by the term
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: projection.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The Intelligible, [Greek: To noeton]. This word in Plato and Platonic
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: writers has a various signification: for, in the first place, whatever is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: exempt from sensibles, and has its essence separate from them, is said to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: be intelligible, and in this sense soul is intelligible. In the second
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: place, intellect, which is prior to soul, is intelligible. In the third
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: place, that which is more ancient than intellect, which replenishes
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: intelligence and is essentially perfective of it, is called intelligible;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and this is the intelligible which Timaeus in Plato places in the order
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: of a paradigm, prior to the demiurgic intellect and intellectual energy.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: But beyond these is the divine intelligible, which is defined according
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to divine union and hyparxis. For this is intelligible as the object of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: desire to intellect, as giving perfection to and containing it, and as
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the completion of being. The highest intelligible, therefore, is that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which is the hyparxis of the gods; the second, that which is true being,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and the first essence; the third, intellect, and all intellectual life;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and the fourth, the order belonging to soul.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Logismos, reasoning. When applied to divinity as by Plato in the Timaeus,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: signifies a distributive cause of things.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: On account of which; with reference to which; through which; according to
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which, from which; or in which; viz. [Greek: di o, uph' ou, di ou, kath'
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: o, ex ou]. By the first of these terms, Plato is accustomed to denominate
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the final cause; by the second the paradigmatic; by the third, the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: demiurgic; by the fourth, the instrumental; by the fifth, form; and by
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the sixth, matter.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Orectic. This word is derived from [Greek: orexis], appetite.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Paradigm, [Greek: paradeigma]. A pattern, or that with reference to which
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: a thing is made.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato

text: a connection with time.

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: A Politician, [Greek: politikos]. This word, as Mr. Sydenham justly
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: observes in his notes in the Rivals, is of a very large and extensive
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: import as used by Plato, and the other ancient writers on politics: for
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: it includes all those statesmen or politicians in aristocracies and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: democracies, who were, either for life, or for a certain time, invested
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with the whole or a part of kingly authority, and the power thereto
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: belonging. See the Politicus.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Prudence, [Greek: Phronesis]. This word frequently means in Plato and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Platonic writers, the habit of discerning what is good in all moral
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: actions, and frequently signifies intelligence, or intellectual
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Perception. The following admirable explanation of this word is given by
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Jamblichus Prudence having a precedaneous subsistence, receives its
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: generation from a pure and perfect intellect. Hence it looks to intellect
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: itself, is perfected by it, and has this as the measure and most
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: beautiful paradigm of all its energies. If also we have any communion
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: with the gods, it is especially effected by this virtue; and through this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: we are in the highest degree assimilated to them. The knowledge too of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: such things as are good, profitable, and beautiful, and of the contraries
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to these, is obtained by this virtue; and the judgment and correction of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: works proper to be done are by this directed. And in short it is a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: certain governing leader of men, and of the whole arrangement of their
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: nature; and referring cities and houses, and the particular life, of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: every one to a divine paradigm, it forms them according to the best
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: similitude; obliterating some things and purifying others. So that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: prudence renders its possessors similar to divinity. Jamblic. apud.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Stob. p. 141.

author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Psychical, [Greek: psychikos]. Pertaining to soul.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Science. This word is sometimes defined by Plato to be that which assigns
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the causes of things; sometimes to be that the subjects of which have a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: perfectly stable essence; and together with this, he conjoins the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: assignation of cause from reasoning. Sometimes again he defines it to be
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that the principles of which are not hypotheses; and, according to this
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: definition, he asserts that there is one science which ascends as far as
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to the principle of things. For this science considers that which is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: truly the principle as unhypothetic, has for its subject true being, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: produces its reasonings from cause. According to the second definition,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: he calls dianoetic knowledge science; but according to the first alone,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: he assigns to physiology the appellation of science.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The telestic art. The art pertaining to mystic ceremonies.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Theurgic. This word is derived from [Greek: Theourgia], or that religious
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: operation which deifies him by whom it is performed as much as is possible
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: to man.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: Truth, [Greek: aletheia]. Plato, following ancient theologists, considers
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: truth multifariously. Hence, according to his doctrine, the highest truth
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: is characterized by unity, and is the light proceeding from the good,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which imparts purity, as he says in the Philebus, and union, as he says
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: in the Republic, to intelligibles. The truth which is next to this in
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: dignity is that which proceeds from intelligibles, and illuminates the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: intellectual orders, and which an essence unfigured, uncolored, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: without contact, first receives, where also the plain of truth is
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: situated, as it is written in the Phaedrus. The third kind of truth is,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: that which is connascent with souls, and which through intelligence comes
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: into contact with true being. For the psychical light is the third, from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the intelligible; intellectual deriving its plenitude from intelligible
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: light, and the psychical from the intellectual. And the last kind of
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: truth is that which is full of error and inaccuracy through sense, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: the instability of its object. For a material nature is perpetually
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: flowing, and is not naturally adapted to abide even for a moment.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The following beautiful description of the third kind of truth, or that
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: which subsists in souls, is given by Jamblichus: "Truth, as the name
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: implies, makest a conversion about the gods and their incorporeal energy;
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: but, doxastic imitation, which, as Plato says, is fabricative of images,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: wanders about that which is deprived of divinity and is dark. And the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: former indeed receives its perfection in intelligible and divine forms,
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: and real beings which have a perpetual sameness of subsistence; but the
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: latter looks to that which is formless, and non-being, and which has a
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: various subsistence; and, about this it's visive power is blunted. The
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: former contemplates that which is, but the latter assumes such a form as
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: appears to the many. Hence the former associates with intellect, and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: increases the intellectual nature which we contain; but the latter, from
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: looking to that which always seems to be, hunts after folly and
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: deceives." Jamblic. apud Stob. p. 136.
title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

title: Introduction to the Philosophy and Writings of Plato
author: Taylor, Thomas

text: The unical, [Greek: to niaion]. That which is characterized by unity.
